titlestmt.title: There is No Natural Religion copy D : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 90KB; 18 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 66KB to 583KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC Libraries August 2015
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of electronic editions of There is No Natural Religion, copies A, D, and M, from the British Museum, Houghton Library, and Victoria and Albert Museum respectively. They join copy B, from Yale Center for British Art, copy C, from the Library of Congress, and copies G1-2 and L, from the Morgan Library and Museum. The Archive now has all seven extant copies of this illuminated book, making There is No Natural Religion the sixth illuminated book with its entire publishing history reproduced in the Archive, joining The Song of Los, Milton a Poem, All Religions are One, The Book of Ahania, and The Book of Los. The Archive will add The Marriage of Heaven and Hell to the list later this year. There is No Natural Religion was composed and executed in 1788, shortly after All Religions are One. These were Blake's first works in illuminated printing, though no copy of either work survives from this date. Blake composed twenty plates for There is No Natural Religion plates in two antithetical sets (a and b series). Only copy L consists exclusively of the ten b series of plates. The other twelve recorded copies of this book share impressions of the same group of either eight or twelve plates, which appeared to be merely incomplete sets of impressions until it was discovered that six of these copies were 19th-century reproductions. Once the inauthentic impressions were weeded out, it became apparent that what remained was Blake's selection of a and b plates for an abridged version of the work printed around 1794.
With the publication of There is No Natural Religion copies A, D, and M, the Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of 95 copies of Blake's nineteen illuminated books in the context of full bibliographic information about each work, careful diplomatic transcriptions of all texts, detailed descriptions of all images, and extensive bibliographies. New protocols for transcription, which produce improved accuracy and fuller documentation in editors' notes, have been applied to all copies of There is No Natural Religion in the Archive. With the Archive's Compare feature, users can easily juxtapose multiple impressions of any plate across all or selected copies of this or any of the other illuminated books and, with the Virtual Lightbox, users can examine any images in the Archive, as well as crop, zoom, and juxtapose them for close study.
In addition to illuminated books, the Archive contains many important manuscripts and series of engravings, sketches, and water color drawings, including Blake's illustrations to Thomas Gray's Poems, water color and engraved illustrations to Dante's Divine Comedy, the large color printed drawings of 1795 and c. 1805, the Linnell and Butts sets of the Book of Job water colors and the sketchbook containing drawings for the engraved illustrations to the Book of Job, the water color illustrations to Robert Blair's The Grave, and all nine of Blake's water color series illustrating the poetry of John Milton.
In December 2014, the Archive launched a new wing, which contains searchable HTML and PDF editions of thirty-nine past issues of Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly published from 2000 through 2009. PDF versions present the journal as originally published, but the HTML versions are re-implemented with many full-color images from the Blake Archive, making it possible for users to link directly to those works that have been published in the Archive.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist"The Author & Printer W Blake" is etched in reverse at the bottom of Object 1. In this copy, the lettering is partly obscured by coloring.

imprint.publisher: William BlakeBlake is named as the printer on the frontispiece, but he is also the "publisher."
imprint.pubplace: London The place of publication is not given in the work, but Blake was living in London at the time of its composition and etching. He was living in the London suburb of Lambeth at the time of its printing.

objinfo.objorder: Bentley Plates a1, a2, b3, a5-a9, b12The leaves are loose and thus the binding order cannot be determined definitively. The order given here follows the standard sequence established by the frontispiece (Object 1), the title page (Object 2), the sequence of roman numeral headings I-VI etched at the tops of Objects 3-8, and the plate with text beginning "Therefore" (Object 9). Placing Bentley Plate b3 as Object 3 may seem odd, because it comes at the start of a group of "a" series plates, but this is the only way to complete the sequence of roman numeral headings I-VI. An alternative to this arrangement would be to place Bentley Plate b3 as the penultimate object, just before Bentley Plate b12 and thereby keeping the "b" series plates together. The pen and ink numbers far top left or top right on Objects 1-3, 7-9 (see Penned Numbers, below) suggest a different order, but these numbers are not by Blake and have no authority. These numbers are not displayed here.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 4.7 x 3.7 cm. and 6.1 x 4.6 cm.
objinfo.leafsize: 13.9 x 10.9 cm. (Objects 1-3 and 9), 13.2 x 10.1 cm. (Object 4), 13.4 x 10.7 cm. (Objects 5-8)
objinfo.medium: relief etching with touches of white-line etching on some plates, rudimentary color printing on Objects 1, 3-9, and hand coloring in water colors on Object 1
objinfo.printingstyle: relief, with rudimentary color printing on Objects 1, 3-9
objinfo.inkcolor: burnt umber (Object 1), black (Object 2), and olive brown (Objects 3-9)
objinfo.etchednumbers: noneThe etched numbers I-VI on objects 3-8 are headings, not plate numbers.
objinfo.pennednumbers: 1, 2, and 4 on Objects 1-3, 5 on Object 7, 6 on Object 8, and 3 on Object 9These numbers, far top left or right, are not by Blake and have no authority. They are not displayed here.
objinfo.binding: noneThe stab holes (see below) indicate that the plates were once bound, probably in the nineteenth century.
objinfo.stabholes: 11?There are at least 11 stab holes. Those in Object 1, the frontispiece, are in the right margin, indicating that it was formerly bound facing Object 2, the title page.

provenance.name: Houghton Library, Harvard University
provenance.note: Early history not known; acquired no later than 1891 by Edward William Hooper; his daughter Mrs. Greely Curtis, probably by inheritance in 1901; given by Hooper's daughters to Harvard University in July 1941.

repository.addressline: Department of Printing and Graphic Arts

desc.objtitle:
There is No Natural Religion,
Object 1 (Bentley a1, Erdman a1, Keynes a2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two youthful males, both nude and with curly hair, stand on the right. The youth furthest to the right appears to have his left arm raised and may have his left hand resting on (or perhaps through?) the tree trunk near the right margin. The youth furthest to the left holds a shepherd's crook in his right hand, although this prints as only a line with no visible top in this copy. On the left is a seated couple; both the old man, with a long beard, and the woman wear gowns. The man may be seated on a fluted pillar. The woman may have long hair or be wearing drapery (a scarf?) over her head. Another tree stands along the left margin; its branches and leaves form a canopy over the seated figures. Mountains dominate the distant landscape.

component.illusobjdesc: A youthful male, nude and with curly hair, stands on the right. He appears to have his left arm raised, perhaps with his left hand resting on (or perhaps through?) the tree trunk near the right margin. His right arm is at his side. His body suggests a contrapposto posture. He looks down and to the left.

A youthful male, nude and with curly hair, stands to the left of another such figure. He holds a shepherd's crook in his right hand, although this prints only as a line with no distinct top in this copy. At least his right arm is by his side. His face is partly turned to the right; he may be looking at his companion.

An old, bearded man with long hair sits on what is likely a fluted pillar. He wears a long gown and looks to the right. His right arm is slightly bent and may rest on the pillar that he is seated on; his left arm appears to rest on his knee.

A woman sits behind and to the right of the old bearded man. She wears a gown and has drapery (a scarf?) over her head. Her left arm rests at her side. Though she faces right like the man beside her, she turns her head slightly to look forward, perhaps at her companion.
Shadows, perhaps from the tree above, darken the ground in the lower left corner of the plate.
A tree stands on the right. Its branches and perhaps some leaves spread out near the top of the plate.
A tree stands on the left. Its branches and leaves form a canopy at the top of the plate.
The old, bearded man on the left sits on what appears to be a fluted pillar.
The landscape background is dominated by two ranges of hills or mountains.
The green coloring of the hills or mountains in the background suggests they are covered in grass.
The orange coloring in the middle distance of the landscape suggests either bare earth or a mature crop.

lg.l: The Author & Printer W BlakeIn reverse lettering, partly obscured by color printing in black.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 2 (Bentley a2, Erdman a2, Keynes a2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The Gothic structure of spires and arches filling most of the plate may be a church facade, a church portal, a church window, or an imaginative variation on a tomb canopy of the sort Blake saw (and probably drew) in Westminster Abbey during his apprentice years. The tracery includes at least seven human figures; the largest, upper center, may be the Virgin Mary (who more clearly holds the Christ child in other copies). She is flanked on each side by two praying figures. On each side of the design, between sets of spires, are a pair of standing figures, one arranged above the other. Perhaps we are to think of all these figures as statues in stone. The words of the title are incorporated into the design.

component.illusobjdesc: The Gothic structure of spires and arches filling most of the plate may be a church facade, a church portal, the tracery of a church window, or an imaginative variation on a tomb canopy of the sort Blake saw (and probably drew) in Westminster Abbey during his apprentice years. Perhaps were are to think of this architectural confection as being built of stone.

The largest figure in the design stands above the title word "There." The figure appears to be gowned and may be holding a small child or baby in (her?) left arm, although this small form is more clearly printed in other copies. If so, this figure group suggests the Virgin Mary and the Christ child. Given the context, this may be a statute in stone.

The figure standing above title word "There" may be holding a baby or small child (more clearly printed in other copies). If so, then this may be the Virgin Mary and the Christ child. Given the context, this may be a statue in stone.

A gowned figure, apparently with hands together in prayer and looking up and to the right, stands above the first two letters of the title word "There." Given the context, this may be a statue in stone.
A gowned figure, apparently with hands together in prayer and looking to the left, stands or kneels above the final letter of the title word "There." Given the context, this may be a statue in stone.

Difficult to distinguish in this copy, a small gowned figure stands rigidly among the Gothic tracery left of "There" in the title inscription. Given the setting, this may be a saint; the architectural context suggests that this is a statue in stone.

A small gowned figure stands rigidly among the Gothic tracery left of "Religion" in the title inscription. The figure's right arm may be raised, bent at the elbow before his/her chest. Given the setting, this may be a saint; the architectural context suggests that this is a statue in stone.

A small gowned figure stands rigidly among the Gothic tracery right of "No" in the title inscription. Given the setting, this may be a saint; the architectural context suggests that this is a statue in stone.

A small gowned figure stands rigidly among the Gothic tracery right of "Religion" in the title inscription. His/her arms appear to be at his/her side. Given the setting, this may be a saint; the architectural context suggests that this is a statue in stone.
The title words are incorporated within the design. Perhaps we are to think of the words as inscribed in stone or on a door.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 3 (Bentley b3, Erdman b3, Keynes b3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned figure of indeterminate gender lies on the ground facing forward. The figure appears to prop its upper body up on its elbows. In other copies, the figure may read, write, or hold a book. On the left is a clump of vegetation or perhaps the stump of a tree.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned figure of indeterminate gender lies on the ground facing forward. The figure appears to prop its upper body up on its elbows and may wear its hair in a bun. In other copies, the figure may read, write, or hold a book.
There is a clump of vegetation, or perhaps the stump of a tree, in the lower left corner of the plate.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vines or several branches spring from the first letter of the text and arch to the right.

component.illusobjdesc: Vines or several branches spring from the first letter of the text and arch to the right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A scroll-like vine curls right of the last line of text and above the figure.

component.illusobjdesc: A scroll-like vine curls right of the last line of text and above the figure.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 4 (Bentley a5, Erdman a5, Keynes a5)

objnote.p: The leaf is inscribed, lower left in brown ink, "W. Blake: Sc" followed by another letter, possible "t" as an abbreviation for "sculpsit." This inscription is not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A woman, with long or medium-length hair and wearing a long gown, kneels on the ground. She looks down and to the right at a young child she holds around the waist with her extended right arm and hand (left arm not pictured). The child, also kneeling and facing right, is probably male; he may also be gowned. He extends his arms horizontally toward a small bird near the right margin. These motifs may relate to the theme of "desires" (Erdman page 2) first raised textually on plate a8. The background, right of the woman and above the child, is filled with a clump of trees. Tall grass or other indeterminate vegetation grows above and behind the woman at left. A large, leafless tree grows up the left margin and spreads a branch between the heading number ("II") and the first line of text. Dark shadows appear to cover the ground along the bottom edge of the plate.

component.illusobjdesc: A woman, with long or medium-length hair and wearing a long gown, kneels on the ground. She looks down and to the right at a young child she holds around the waist with her extended right arm and hand (left arm not pictured).

A young child, probably male and gowned, kneels on the ground and faces to the right. While being held by a woman on the left, the child reaches, arms extended horizontally, toward a small bird near the right margin.
A bird flies from the grasp of a child.
The landscape background is filled with trees.
Tall grass or other indeterminate vegetation grows above and behind the woman at left.
A leafless tree grows up the left margin. One if its branches extends between the heading number ("II") and the first line of text.
Dark shadows cover the ground along the bottom edge of the plate.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 5 (Bentley a6, Erdman a6, Keynes a6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A man, with curly hair and perhaps also a beard, sits on the ground. He may be wearing a gown, as indicated by folds over his left hip. He is facing to the left and reaching with both arms in the same direction. His legs are extended horizontally to the left. A winged and nude putto, visible from the waist up, appears behind the seated man's legs. This second figure looks to the right and reaches toward, and perhaps touches, the seated man's right shoulder with his left hand. The putto's right arm is raised, with one finger of his right hand pointing heavenward. This gesture, and simply the winged child himself, may indicate the spiritual perceptions not available to the "3 senses" (Erdman page 2). A slender tree or vine, intertwined with a second vine, grows up the right margin and extends in loops horizontally above and below the heading number ("III") and terminates in three spirals. There may be some plants left of the putto, lower left. Dark shadows appear to cover the ground beneath the man in the lower right corner of the plate.

component.illusobjdesc: A man with curly hair, who may also have a beard(?), sits on the ground. He may be wearing a gown, as indicated by folds over his left hip. He is facing to the left, with legs extended in the same direction, and reaching with both arms to the left. His left palm is probably down, his right palm faces out toward the viewer.

A winged putto, seen from the waist up, appears behind the legs of the seated man. The putto's left arm is extended horizontally; his left hand reaches toward, and may touch, the right shoulder of the seated man. The putto's right arm is raised and a finger on his right hand points heavenward. There are no clear indications of clothing.
A slender tree or vine, intertwined with a second vine, grows up the right margin and extends in loops horizontally above and below the heading number ("III") and terminates in three spirals.
A vine is intertwined around the tree or vine growing up the right margin. This second vine seems to end in the top right corner; the larger tree or vine extends horizontally to the left margin.
There may be some plants left of the putto, lower left.
Dark shadows appear to cover the ground beneath the man in the lower right corner of the plate.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 6 (Bentley a7, Erdman a7, Keynes a7)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A man, perhaps wearing tights or some other body-hugging costume, sits on the ground with his back against a tree. He is playing a pipe, held near his mouth with his right hand and lower on the pipe with his left. He faces to the right, with his legs extended to the right and crossed at the knee. He wears a hat, decorated with what appear to be feathers. The landscape on the right is composed of a low hill and a grove of trees or other indeterminate vegetation. A single tree extends up the left margin, its base visible to the left of the piper and its top visible to the left of lines 1-2 of the text. Three birds fly in the sky above the text and on each side of the heading number ("IV").

component.illusobjdesc: A man, perhaps wearing tights or some other body-hugging costume, sits on the ground with his back against a tree. He is playing a pipe, held near his mouth with his right hand and lower on the pipe with his left. He faces to the right, with his legs extended to the right and crossed at the knee. He wears a hat, decorated with what appear to be two or three feathers. Although clearer in other copies, he may also wear a hoop earring in his right ear.
The landscape above the seated figure includes a low hill and a grove of trees or other indeterminate vegetation.
The landscape above the seated figure includes a low hill and a grove of trees or other indeterminate vegetation.
A tree grows up the left margin, its base visible to the left of the piper and its top visible to the left of lines 1-2 of the text. One short branch arches to the right near the top of the plate.
Three birds fly above the text, one left of the heading number ("IV") and two right of the number.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 7 (Bentley a8, Erdman a8, Keynes a8)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A boy with curly hair strides, right foot forward, back and to the left. He wears knee-length breeches and perhaps a shirt. With arms extended horizontally to the left and fingers spread open on at least his left hand, he reaches toward a duck or swan floating on a small body of water (perhaps a river or lake). The boy's gestures suggest the theme of "Mans desires" (Erdman page 2) in the text. A tree, with an intertwined vine, grows up the left margin. One of the tree's branches, perhaps bearing a few spiky leaves, arches over the heading number and text at the top of the plate. A dark shadow extends along the ground from the base of the tree on the left to the boy's feet on the right.

component.illusobjdesc: A boy with short, curly hair strides, right foot forward, back and to the left. He wears knee-length breeches and perhaps a shirt. With arms extended horizontally to the left and fingers spread open on at least his left hand, he reaches toward a duck or swan on the left.
A duck or swan floats on a small body of water, perhaps a lake or river. The bird faces to the right.
A tree grows up the left margin of the plate. One of its branches, bearing a few spiky leaves, arches over the heading number and text at the top of the plate.
A vine is entwined around the lower half of the tree near the left margin.
The bird lower left appears to be floating on a small body of water, perhaps a lake or river.
A dark shadow extends along the ground from the base of the tree on the left to the boy's feet on the right.

lg.l: ons. none can de. The slightly raised dot at the end of the line may be a fragment of a hyphen.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 8 (Bentley a9, Erdman a9, Keynes a9)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A figure of indeterminate gender who may be gowned lies on the ground with legs extended to the left and perhaps crossed. He or she props up its upper body with its arms. The figure may hold its head in its left hand in a posture traditionally associated with melancholy, though this is clearer in other copies. The long, spiky leaves of two plants, or exceptionally long grasses, arch over his head from both the right and left sides of the plate. A tree grows up the right margin; its branches and leaves extend horizontally along the top of the plate. A vine is entwined around the tree's trunk. One tendril of the vine terminates in a lily-like flower just above and slightly to the right of the figure's head.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure of indeterminate gender who may be gowned lies on the ground with legs extended to the left and perhaps crossed. He or she props up its upper body with its arms. The figure may hold its head in its left hand in a posture traditionally associated with melancholy, though this is clearer in other copies.
The long leaves of two plants, or very long grasses, arch over the figure.
A tree grows up the right margin. Its branches and leaves extend horizontally along the top margin of the plate.
A vine is intertwined around the tree near the right margin of the plate. One of the vine's tendrils terminates in a lily-like flower just above and slightly to the right of the figure's head.

desc.objtitle:
,
Object 9 (Bentley b12, Erdman b12, Keynes b12)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably male, lies supine on a bed, bier, orâif he is of great sizeâon hills. His legs may be crossed at the knees. His right arm dangles rather limply at his side. There are no clear indications of clothing. Perhaps he is sleeping or dead. Lines of radiance appear around his head. This last motif suggests that this may be Christ, the "God" who "becomes as we are" (Erdman page 3) in the text. Shadows darken the forms beneath the figure.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably male, lies supine on a bed, bier, orâif he is of great sizeâon hills. His legs may be crossed at the knees. His right arm dangles rather limply at his side. There are no clear indications of clothing. Perhaps he is sleeping or dead. Lines of radiance appear around his head. This last motif suggests that this may be Christ, the "God" who "becomes as we are" (Erdman page 3) in the text.
Shadows darken what may be a bed, bier, or hills beneath the supine figure.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several vines decorate the spaces on all sides of the first line of text ("Therefore"). A single vine appears above the first four letters. Though nearly indistinguishable here, in other copies there is a vine with three branches left of the word. A vine with a single loop and perhaps some leaves grows at the end of the word. Two vines lie beneath the word; the one on the right has a single loop and terminates in three leaves or small flowers. A horizontal line separates the text from the design below.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine appears above the first four letters of "Therefore" (line 1). Though nearly indistinct here, in other copies there is also a vine with three branches left of the word.
A vine with a single loop and perhaps long, slender leaves at its termination appears in the margin right of "Therefore."
A vine, perhaps with a few small leaves, appears under the first four letters of "Therefore."
A vine with a single loop appears beneath and to the right of the last four letters of "Therefore." It terminates in three leaves or small flowers.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine descends in the margin right of the third and fourth lines of text.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine descends in the margin right of the third and fourth lines of text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine appears left of the last line of text ("is").

component.illusobjdesc: A vine appears left of the last line of text ("is").
A horizontal line separates the text from the design below.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with two loops descends right of the last line of text ("is") and into the space between the text and the illustration at the bottom of the plate. The vine bears several leaves or small flowers.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine with two loops descends right of the last line of text ("is") and into the space between the text and the illustration at the bottom of the plate. The vine bears several leaves or small flowers.
